body: Thanks @exceptionfactory for updating. I'm a +1 on the changes. Will merge as soon as Github Actions complete.

Yeah, I think I would also agree that defaulting the `dropUnknownFields` to `true` makes the most sense. One place where I can think of where we need to be careful that we're doing the right thing is `ValidateRecord` but that Processor is explicitly passing a value for the field:
```
while ((record = reader.nextRecord(coerceTypes, false)) != null) {
    ...
}
```

And any case in which we infer the schema, we should have an entry for every field that is found because we infer the schema based on scanning all records in the flowfile first.

So I think it makes sense to drop unknown fields. It also is consistent with what the JavaDocs state will happen :) So I'm a +1 on that approach.
Thanks @markap14 - will update the PR shortly
@grishick I corrected the formatting in `PGDelete` and rebased to address the one-line merge conflict. The latest version should be ready to merge shortly.
Looks like all builds are looking good. +1 merged to main. Thanks again @exceptionfactory
Changing the default has impacts across many unit tests and I'll need to spend more time looking into this. I just pushed what I currently have and I switched this PR to draft mode.

Seems to build.   But the bundled dependencies of Spring seem considerable and likely avoidable.  The LICENSE/NOTICE is unchanged but clearly does need to change.

Seems like at least a few modules also included that are likely in a parent class loader.  Reviewing further but this is a good example of a dependency where maintenance jumps (major lines no less) are much more than bumping versions.
Although for clarification, it looks like the `NOTICE` files are outdated, so I agree they should be updated to reflect current contents and versions.

Thanks for moving this forward @pvillard31. Reviewing the changes locally, I found the `dropUnknownFields` check in `MapRecord` was blocking the record field from being updated. Removing that check seems to have yielded the expected behavior, but still evaluating the impact. I pushed a commit with that change, along with optimizing the field removal handling to avoid creating the deep copy of the JsonNode when that is not necessary.
Closing due to incorrect Jira issue number.

Thanks @exceptionfactory @pvillard31 I think the changes here make a lot of sense. I did some testing locally with ConvertRecord and UpdateRecord and everything appears to work as expected. Also ran a quick performance comparison before/after these changes and saw roughly the same numbers so all good there. I'm a +1 on these changes.
The integration test failures are unrelated to these changes and highlight a separate issue with the SNMP4J dependency. Planning to evaluate that in a separate Jira issue.
PR #9469 resolves the integration test failures.

Thanks for the test fixes @exceptionfactory!

I suggest also removing the unsupported MD5 and SHA items from the allowable values of `SNMP Authentication Protocol` [property](https://github.com/apache/nifi/blob/c68f6910baed5167ecc85cd78f75f9696de42df5/nifi-extension-bundles/nifi-snmp-bundle/nifi-snmp-processors/src/main/java/org/apache/nifi/snmp/processors/properties/V3SecurityProperties.java#L98). It can be done in a separate jira/PR if the current scope is the test fixes only.

It can be done in a separate jira/PR if the current scope is the test fixes only.

Thanks @turcsanyip, addressing those in a separate Jira issue would be good.

Thank you for the contribution and providing the motivation behind this change, @pvillard31. 

I think it makes a lot of sense to be able to exclude directories from being detected as buckets. 

Does it make sense to allow users to define a pattern of paths to exempt as buckets, instead of hard-coding to ignore any "hidden", dot-prefixed directories? 
The default value still could be `[.].*` but users would be able to exclude other directories as well, e.g. `ci` or `docs`.

Hey @EndzeitBegins - thanks for the feedback! I don't think it's really needed here but I'm definitely not against adding a property if you feel like this is better (I just tried to keep configuration super easy). The reason why I don't think this is needed is because, if the repo is used only for flows, then it would look like:

````
- .github
- bucket1
- bucket2
````
But if the repo is going to be for more than just flows, then the registry client would be configured with a repo path (`flows`) and it would be something like:

````
- .github
- flows
  - bucket1
  - bucket2
- docs
````

Having said that... are you aware of CI/CD stacks that would create/expect a non hidden directory at the root level?

I've seen projects having a dedicated `ci` or `jenkins` directory in the past. That's what I was thinking about. 

Another thing that comes to mind is that users might want to store automated tests for a Flow inside the same repository as the Flow, resulting in a `src` or `my-flow-tests` directory of sorts. 

However, as both the `GitLabFlowRegistryProvider` and `GitHubFlowRegistryProvider` are still very new it might be fair to assume that users can still opt for an explicit repository path in case they use non-"hidden" directories, as you've outlined above. 

Keeping the configuration as simple as possible sounds reasonable. Should the need arise in the future,  we still could introduce a property later on while preserving the now statically defined behaviour. 
Having said that I'm now in favour of this change as is. 

Thank you for the contribution once more @pvillard31. 

Code changes look straightforward. Does it make sense to manifest the behaviour with a test case though, to ensure it's not altered by accident in the future?

I've not been using Jenkins in ages but if it expects a directory like that, I can add a property and we just save ourselves from another change in the future. Regarding potential files next to the flow definitions, I'm currently designing/working on some flow testing capabilities so I'll definitely catch any issue in case the clients are not happy with this scenario.

I'll update the current PR.
Changes look good to me. üëçüèª Thank you for the adjustments, adding a test case and especially the feedback.

Hello - we very strongly want and will avoid adding dependencies to this component so the pom change must not occur. 

We also do not intend to restore bypassing hostname verification or weakening it at this point.  We'd need to more fully articulate the why/motivation and how it doesn't weaken security.  See comments on the JIRA.

We'll plan to close this PR as-is unless pending further discussion and/or modification.

@xnox Thanks for reviewing. There is a separate effort underway [1] that will migrate the Registry UI into `nifi-frontend` which will include targeting some of the outdated dependencies you've noted.

While there are no noted dependencies with CVEs for UpdateAttribute Advanced UI, that is also undergoing the same migration [2].

[1] https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NIFI-13940
[2] https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NIFI-13710
Due to comments about the nature of this PR subject to change going to close for now.  Please open a new one as available.

This proposal introduces security issues that bypass the cryptographic guarantees of TLS certificate verification. This kind of approach may be considered for specialized use cases in a custom component, but this is not something that can be considered for inclusion in the project itself due to the inherent security risks.
Going to close for now as this is not on a path to merging.

Thanks @pgyori I agree with @exceptionfactory's assessment on the Exception handling that it could be handled a bit more cleanly, and perhaps the `toMap` method should not be separate from the `to_dictionary` method. The only other concern that I would have was the one mentioned inline about what is actually being tested in the Exception handling case, as it doesn't really verify exactly what is happening. Otherwise I'm a +1. The code is well written and makes a lot of sense. And otherwise the tests are good and reasonable. Thanks for working on this!
Here is a PR for `main` branch with the same change: https://github.com/apache/nifi/pull/9483
Reviewing....

I don't believe this PR introduces a breaking change, I believe it fixes a breaking change.  The ConvertRecord documentation says "If any field is present in the input (schema) that is not present in the output (schema), the field will be left out of the output."  This functionality broke in 1.26.0.

This is a trade-off decision because yes it's possible that an existing 1.25.0 flow broke in 1.26.0 and was remediated.  If this PR is accepted for 1.28.1, then it could break those flows again.

@mosermw - I definitely agree that this can be seen as fixing a bug / unwanted behavior.

However, the default value in `nextRecord` has been unchanged for many years so if a breaking change happened between 1.25 and 1.26, I don't think it was in this part of the code. And this change potentially impacts any reader, not just JSON. I'm specifically thinking about flows dealing with XML data. But as I said, I'm not against this backport as long as this is made super clear - and given the ongoing discussion for 1.x EOL, I don't think there would be another release to revert this change if needed.

Minor nitpick, but the last line is missing a line ending in the DISCLAIMER files.

In the Unix/-like world, a line in a text file is ending by a line ending `
` by definition. On Windows, `
` is more like a line separator, so adding it after the last line is not needed. I prefer the Unix way. Normally text editors on Linux (and I think macOS too) add this automatically, but some IDEs follow the Windows convention, except using a Unix `
` line ending character as their line separator when on Linux/macOS.
i added a commit to ensure each disclaimer ends with a newline.

That is an extremely valid point that I completely missed. Given that some users definitely want to restrict processors with access to local file system, it feels like we shouldn't change expectations around GenerateFlowFile and a dedicated processor for this specific usage would be better. What do you think?

> That is an extremely valid point that I completely missed. Given that some users definitely want to restrict processors with access to local file system, it feels like we shouldn't change expectations around GenerateFlowFile and a dedicated processor for this specific usage would be better. What do you think?

Yes, under the circumstances, it seems like a separate Processor would be better. I think it would be good to scope out what it looks like on the Jira issue and then move to consider the implementation.

> a dedicated processor for this specific usage would be better. What do you think?

Thinking about it, a separate processor might make sense insofar that the processor is not actually "generating" content but rather injecting pre-defined content when using the contents of a file (although the same could be said about the existing "Custom Text")
Thanks for all the feedback @exceptionfactory @EndzeitBegins. Will close this PR, update the JIRA and file a new one that will introduce a new processor.

Thanks again for your work on this improvement @grishick. I have merged the corresponding pull request for the main branch and closed the Jira issue.

Voting is [currently in progress](https://lists.apache.org/thread/4wgrlytm3xgsc67l32m83rl2g77dsqvs) to declare the NiFi version 1 series as End of Support in a few weeks. We are moving to wrap up a 1.28.1 patch release version soon, and we are not considering new features, so I'm closing this pull request for the support branch.
Thanks for the review @exceptionfactory - I pushed a commit to address your comments

Thank you for the addition @pvillard31.
I just glanced over the code, so I might've missed something, but the overall code looked good to me. 

I just wondered, Is there a particular reason to have a distinct property for adding a `mime.type` attribute? 
From what I've gathered users can add arbitrary attributes to the resulting FlowFile using dynamic properties. There are other [Core attributes](https://github.com/apache/nifi-api/blob/main/src/main/java/org/apache/nifi/flowfile/attributes/CoreAttributes.java) used quite regularly by other processors, such as `filename`.

Just trying to understand, is there a reason we explicitly want / need a property for this particular attribute? 
If not, we might not introduce a separate property and simplify the implementation even further?
@exceptionfactory oops my bad! I've added unit tests and fixed the erroring ones.

@EndzeitBegins - you're right that people could use dynamic properties (assuming they read the docs and see that they can use dynamic properties). The fact that `mime.type` is "special" is that this attribute is used to automatically choose the right content viewer when looking at the content of the flow file in the UI. This is why this one is made available as a dedicated property in GenerateFlowFile and I took the same approach here.
Thanks @EndzeitBegins - I pushed a commit with your recommendations
Thanks @bobpaulin changes look good +1 merged to main
Thanks @pvillard31 changes look good +1 merged to main

Thanks @mcgilman I ran a bunch of tests, copying & pasting locally as well as copying from 1 instance and pasting to another. Tested simple processors/connections. Tested child groups. Tested with Controller Services. Tested with Parameter Contexts and references. Tested sensitive properties were removed, but not those that reference parameters. Tested Controller Service A referencing Controller Service B. Tested Processors with multiple Controller Services. Tested references to external Controller Services when (a) the external services doesn't exist in the destination instance (b) the external service does exist in the destination instance.

Everything worked flawlessly. Code review looks good to me as well. I'm a +1! Many thanks for adding this feature, I'm very excited to be able to do this!

I have also added the processor bulletins:

> A few things I noticed while using it...
> 
> After transitioning from running -> stopped or stopped -> running, the dialog isn't fully in edit/readonly mode respectively.
> 
> * Meaning, if I start a processor that was stopped when I opened the dialog, the button makes the appropriate transition to "Close" and the form won't submit. But the the property editors appear editable and the inputs on the relationships tab remain enabled.
> * Inversely, stopping processor that was running when opening the dialog, the dialog becomes "Apply"able but the property editors remain in a read-only state as well as the inputs on the relationships tab.

@rfellows please check these again as they should be working now.
